author: Malcolm Pein , Chess correspondent
title: Fabiano Caruana out in front
text: Fabiano Caruana outplayed Vladimir Kramnik in round five at Dortmund, Germany before winning a fourth straight game over Hou Yifan. The American, who has recently appointed English IM Lawrence Trent as his agent, took the lead with a game to play. Caruana started slowly and lost to Wesley So in round two, but has 4.5/6, half a point ahead of his final opponent Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu. • Fabiano Caruana shows his silky skills Nisipeanu was a grateful recipient of a Kramnik error in the sixth round when the 14th world champion let him off the hook in a rook-and-pawn endgame. Kramnik is usually ruthlessly efficient in these circumstances. Kramnik played for the win from the outset here. 13.Bxe4!? was bold, 13.Nxe4 dxe4 14.Bxe4 Qxd4 15.Qxd4 Bxd4 16.Bb2! Rxa1 17.Bxa1 Bg7 = was just level while 14.e3 was also equal. V. Kramnik – F. Caruana Gruenfeld g3 1.Nf3 d5 2.g3 g6 3.Bg2 Bg7 4.d4 Nf6 5.0–0 0–0 6.c4 c6 7.Nbd2 a5 8.b3 a4 9.Ba3 axb3 10.axb3 Bf5 11.Nh4 Be6 12.Re1 Ne4 13.Bxe4!? dxe4 14.Nxe4 Qxd4 (14...Bxd4? 15.Bxe7!) 15.Qc2? (15.Qxd4 Bxd4 16.Bb2 Rxa1 17.Bxa1 Bb6 with the edge) 15...Bf5! See board left (Not 15...Qxa1? 16.Rxa1 Bxa1 17.Bxe7. This fine move wins the exchange and must have been overlooked by Kramnik. The Ra1 and Ne4 are loose) 16.Nxf5 gxf5 17.Ng5 (17.Nd2 Qc3! 18.Qa2 Qa5 ; 17.Nc5? Rxa3 18.Rxa3 Qxc5 is even worse) 17...Qg4 18.f4 Bxa1 19.Rxa1 h6 (19...c5! bringing the knight to c6 was even better according to the computer) 20.Nf3 Nd7 21.Rd1 Rxa3 22.Rxd7 Qh3 23.Qc3 e6? (Letting Kramnik back in to the game. 23...Rfa8! 24.Rxe7 Ra1+ 25.Kf2 Rf1+ 26.Ke3 Qg2 with the key point that 27.Qf6 Rxf3+! 28.exf3 Qg1+ is a winning attack) 24.Rxb7 Rfa8 25.Kf2 Ra1 26.Ke3 Rf1 27.Qf6 Rf8 28.Rd7 Rb1 29.Rb7 c5 30.Rb5 Rf1 31.Nd2 (Kramnik had about 10 minutes left here and makes a decisive error. 31.Rxc5!! Qg2 32.Qxh6! Qf2+ 33.Kd3 Rd8+ 34.Kc3 survives by a miracle) 31...Rc1 32.Qb2 (32.Nf3 Qf1! 33.Qxh6 Rc3+ 34.Kd2 Qc1#) 32...Rd1 33.Qc2 Rh1 34.Nf3 Qg2 35.Qc3 How did Caruana create a winning attack? I know what everyone's thinking, but that opening didn't come from @LawrenceTrentIM . Anyway, glad to be back on 50%. — Fabiano Caruana (@FabianoCaruana) June 30, 2015 Answer: 35...Rf1! (Threat Qf2+ followed by Rd8+) 36.Qf6 Rf2 37.Kd3 Rxe2 38.Ng5 Rd2 39.Kc3 Rc2+ 40.Kd3 Qd2# 0–1 Follow @telegraph
